text: murder on the streets of Lahore in broad
daylight a woman in love and pregnant
stoned to death no one intervened to
help
Farzana Parveen was only 25 her bereaved
husband Mohammad Iqbal will now have to
bury her and their unborn child women on
the scene were mourning in front of the
victims shrouded body and they were in
shock this could happen to any of them
the couple were on their way to court
they'd married against the wishes of ms
parveen's parents unthinkable in a
deeply conservative country her family
filed a case for abduction against mr.
Iqbal and the newlyweds were coming to
court to contest it 20 members of her
family were waiting here they tried to
snatch her away from her husband when
she resisted they started pelting her
with stones until she collapsed dead
miss parveen's father surrendered after
the attack but all the others got away
in the aftermath of the stoning
condemnation and indignation so-called
honor killings are common in Pakistan
but stoning in public that's another
level of horror
it's called honor killings and I always
use that in quotation marks because it's
actually this concept that the honour of
the family resides in the woman's body
that the woman is the repository of
honor of the family and the community
and that's not necessarily the case I
mean she has a right to make her own
decisions about her own life many here
in Pakistan are calling this case
already premeditated murder
unfortunately in past cases of so-called
honor killings the attackers got off
very lightly the question now is will
the revolting aspect of this public
stoning make a difference a positive
difference to the way justice is
delivered for women in this country
Kim hottest BBC News Islamabad
